title: Harrowing images of starving grizzly bears as climate change deprives them of food
text:

A gaunt and emaciated family of grizzly bears desperately search for food after their habitat is wiped out due to climate change .

The harrowing pictures were taken close to Knight Inlet on the British Columbia coast by Canadian photographer Rolf Hicker.

A mother brown bear can be seen hunting for the fish along with her two cubs, with her bones and muscles visible through her fur due to her lack of food.

By now grizzly bears should be gorging on fish and berries as they bulk up ahead of their winter hibernation.

Commercial fishermen in the area have called this year the worst salmon season in nearly 50 years.

(Image: Rolf Hicker)

Posting his pictures on Facebook , Mr Hicker wrote: “Worst salmon run here in the Broughton in history I read today. I fully believe it.

“I have not seen a single salmon in a river so far. The bears are starving, and it breaks my heart, seeing this unfold.

“I believe it is important to show this side too. Here in the Broughton is no salmon left for the bears (and whales I must assume?).

“Advertising still shows the happy bears feasting on salmon, well, sorry to say - not here.

“We saw this sow with her two little ones a couple of weeks ago, and then we saw her again only a few days ago.

“I have no idea how she would make it through the winter without salmon.

“I sure prefer to show you beautiful nice wildlife and nature pictures, but it is important and my duty as a photographer to show you this side too.

“We have to protect wild BC salmon - NOW.”

The area is a haven for bear watching with tourists from around the world flocking to the area to see grizzlies in the wild.

The Mamalilikulla First Nation has been monitoring the animals in the region for several years.

Jake Smith, guardian watchman manager for the Mamalilikulla First Nation, told CNN. “The bears are in trouble.”

“They have drastically changed within a couple of months.”

Mr Smith arranged for 500 salmon, donated by A-Tlegay Fisheries Society on Vancouver Island, to be spread along the shorelines that the grizzlies frequent.

(Image: Getty)

He said the bears started eating the fish right away.

“We were about 30 feet away from them,” Mr Smith said.

“A little grizzly looked up at us, and the mother bear came out to get the fish.”

According to a report published in August by the Fisheries and Oceans Canada, the country’s climate is warming twice as fast as the global average impacting salmon’s ecosystems.

The research also blames marine heatwaves, increased floods and droughts as causing significant stress on the fish.

Open-net fish farming is also affecting the wild salmon population spreading disease and pollution in the water, according to critics.

Joy Thorkelson, president of the United Fishermen and Allied Workers’

Union, said: “The impacts of this climate change disaster has been coast wide.”

More than half of Canada’s grizzly population lives in British Columbia, and their average weight is 15 to 62 stones, according to the Nature Conservancy of Canada.
description: WARNING - DISTRESSING IMAGES: Bones and and muscle are visible through the emaciated bear's fur as salmon becomes scarce
